node.title: Sudden divergence during smooth simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi,
This might be a general question I'm struggling with it. I'm sorry if it's not too clear. I would appreciate it if you could take a look.
I am doing THM soil simulations with a source code I have written.
I use the below solver. How do you think it could be improved?
sometimes, while the simulation has been going on for a while smoothly, and things are OK, the solver struggles and diverges. It seems it is due to nothing!
[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -snes_atol '
    petsc_options_value = 'lu 1e-05 '
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  dt = 1200
  end_time = 10368000
[]

I have tried this too:
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package  -snes_atol -snes_rtol -ksp_rtol'
petsc_options_value = 'lu       mumps                          1e-05      1e-10      1e-10'

I once had a similar issue with divergence and I realized I am not setting -snes_atol and the solver diverges when getting close to steady state.
I am quite confused why a smooth process would result in divergence. This is a sample of output, where it starts to shrink the dt and go towards divergence.
AND this is after all the sharp changes have happened (without any problem) and changes are now slow and smooth.

node.title: To have a higher order element for displacement in coupled problems.
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have a THM problem containing Temperature, Pressure, And Displacements.
I was wondering how I could have second-order elements for displacements while keeping first-order for pressure and temperature.
I use Cubit and the Mesh generator of MOOSE.
I used the ORDER feature for the elements but it gave me this error. I am not sure how to specify higher-order elements in the mesh.

This is the input file:
[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 2
ny = 20
xmin = -0.1
xmax = 0.1
ymin = -2
ymax = 0
[]
[Variables]
[temperature]
initial_condition = 274.15
family = LAGRANGE
order = FIRST
scaling = 1e3
[]
[porePressure]
family = LAGRANGE
order = FIRST
scaling = 1e9
[]
[disp_x]
family = LAGRANGE
order = SECOND
[]
[disp_y]
family = LAGRANGE
order = SECOND
[]
[]
I would appreciate your help.
Thanks.

Hello
On a regular MOOSE simulation, this would have been possible.
In THM, it's additional development work if you want to do that. It should not be impossible, @joshuahansel can comment on the expected difficulty
Guillaume
In order to combat this particular error, you can put second_order = true in your Mesh block

ok I misunderstood completely the problem.
For THM simulation you want to add 2nd_order_mesh = true to the GlobalParams block (I think it on a per component basis)
You probably dont have a Mesh block

Thank you, Alex and Guillaume!
Yes, just setting second_order = true in the mesh block was the problem.
I appreciate it.

node.title: Applying Body force in peridynamics module
node.bodyText:
Discussed in #26984

@lindsayad @hchen139
Originally posted by **Narayanan1999** March  6, 2024
Sir, I am following this book 'Peridynamic Theory and Its Applications' which suggest that the tractions are applied in terms of body force. I wanted to apply traction boundary condition on 1D bar. For that I created a bar of 10mm length. I also created a fictitious boundary layer on left end of the bar which is fixed. At the right edge, I created a separate block to apply the body force equivalent to traction boundary.  I am using BPD with horizon number =1.  Distance between two material point is 1mm.  The resulting displacment is varying linearly as expected but it is not matching with the analytical solution. Also, if I increase the mesh, then displacement value at the end is changing in the order of around 10. 
Is there a way to use Body Force kernel properly for peridynamics module? I am attaching my code along with this.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

L=10
H=1
W=1
Hor_num=1
Hn=1
dimension=3
xn=10
yn=1
zn=1
force_dV=100e4

delx=${fparse L/xn}
dely=${fparse H/yn}
delz=${fparse W/zn}
#dV=${fparse delx*dely*delz}
#force_dV= ${fparse force}
M_L_min=${fparse delx/2}
M_L_max=${fparse L-delx/2}
M_H_min=${fparse -dely/2}
M_H_max=${fparse H+dely/2}
M_W_min=${fparse -delz/2}
M_W_max=${fparse W+delz/2}
M_nx=${fparse xn-1}
fb_nx=${fparse Hn}
M_ny=${fparse yn+1}
M_nz=${fparse zn+1}



L_L_min=${fparse M_L_min-Hn*delx}
R_L_max=${fparse M_L_max+delx}

[Mesh]
  type = PeridynamicsMesh
  horizon_number = ${Hor_num}
  [Left_b]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${L_L_min}
    xmax = ${M_L_min}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = ${fb_nx}
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Left_b
	boundary_id_offset = 10
  []
  [Left_b_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Left_b
    subdomain_id = 1
  []
  
  [Mainsec]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${M_L_min}
    xmax = ${M_L_max}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = ${M_nx}
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Mainsec
    boundary_id_offset = 20
  []
  [Mainsec_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Mainsec
    subdomain_id = 2
  []
  [Right_b]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${M_L_max}
    xmax = ${R_L_max}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = 1
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Right_b
	boundary_id_offset = 30
  []
  [Right_b_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Right_b
    subdomain_id = 3
  []
  [combined]
    type = MeshCollectionGenerator
    inputs = 'Left_b_id Mainsec_id Right_b_id'
  []
  construct_side_list_from_node_list=true
  [./gpd]
    type = MeshGeneratorPD
    input = combined
    retain_fe_mesh = false
	blocks_to_pd = '1 2 3'
    merge_pd_blocks = false
    bonding_block_pairs = '1 2; 2 3'
    merge_pd_interfacial_blocks = true
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
  [../]
  [./disp_z]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./node_vol]
  [../]
  [./s11]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./node_area]
    type = NodalVolumePD
    variable = node_vol
  [../]
  [./s11]
    type = NodalRankTwoPD
    variable = s11

	youngs_modulus = 100e9
    poissons_ratio = 0

    rank_two_tensor = stress
	output_type = component
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./left_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 998
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 998
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 998
    value = 0.0
  [../]
[]



[Kernels]
  [./force_x2]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = disp_x
    block = '1003'
    value = ${force_dV}
  [../]
[]


[Modules/Peridynamics/Mechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    formulation = BOND
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 100e9
    poissons_ratio = 0
  [../]

  [./force_density]
    type = ComputeSmallStrainVariableHorizonMaterialBPD
  [../]
  
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type= NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

There are a couple of issues in your input file. First, the BodyForce kernel for FEA cannot directly used for PD simulation. My understanding is that FEA involves a volume integration over an element to determine the equivalent nodal force for the body force. The PD mesh only has line elements and other information such as volume of each PD node is not used in the BodeForce or its parent class to determine the equivalent nodal force.  Instead, for static problem, you can use the ConstantRate nodal kernel to apply the force due to traction, where you will manually calculate the force to be applied to PD nodes. Second, for use of fictitious layer in PD, my understanding is that you only do this for Dirichlet-type BC not Neumann-type BC. Additional comment for the mesh, the current mesh generation is too complicated for this simple problem. It can be greatly simplified.
hchen139 Sir, can you please elaborate on how we can use ConstantRate nodal kernel for applying force due to traction.
@Narayanan1999 please don't create an issue until it's clear it should be one from the Discussion. We should have had this discussion on #26984 instead of here
Converted back to a discussion

I do see that the petsc_dir is not set, however the petsc compile did finish successfully. This is what is at the end of the log file for petsc.
Now to install the library do:
make SLEPC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc PETSC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc install
=========================================
*** Installing SLEPc ***
*** Installing SLEPc at prefix location: /pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/petsc/arch-moose  ***
====================================
Install complete.
Now to check if the libraries are working do (in current directory):
make SLEPC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/petsc/arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose check
====================================
/usr/bin/gmake --no-print-directory -f makefile PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc SLEPC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc install-builtafterslepc
/usr/bin/gmake --no-print-directory -f makefile PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc SLEPC_DIR=/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc slepc4py-install
gmake[6]: Nothing to be done for 'slepc4py-install'.
=========================================

I dont know. It may be tied to how that file is generated.
@milljm

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py", line 19, in <module>
    from packaging import version
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'packaging'
Checking if header needs updating: /pscratch/detorre/raccoon/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
\nFailed to generate MooseRevision.h\n
I now see this. Which is the packaging error. However my python appears to be working, and its pointing to the same version of python that I ran the rebuild scripts with.
Can you conda install packaging ?
I'm on a HPC so I am not using conda
I guess this just has to do with the python package I have loaded and not MOOSE itself

or pip install then
or ask HPC admins to install it for you
note that you CAN still have a local install of conda on a HPC machine and NOT install the moose-dev package

Indeed! I use Conda for all sorts of things not-moose related. For issues exactly like this. I am betting you also have pip available, which does allow you to install to your home directory:
pip install --user packaging
Personally, I prefer the Conda route. As it lets me manage different environments. The above pip install method, will install packaging and be available in all your environments. And while packaging is very benign, others may not be!
Thanks for the advice!

node.title: Make error moose installation
node.bodyText:

I am using ubuntu 20.04.

Hello
So this is a re-install in the same folder?
Did you clean the repo (with git clean -xfD) before re-installing?
Guillaume

yes, I actually cleaned and even removed the folder. The first set of errors come whenever I try fresh install everytime. The second set of errors come when I just try to reinstall on top of first try.
Apologies for confusion. I just wanted to show all the ways I tried to circumvent the problem
What is the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts

Its also possible the issue stems from the  mixing of conda-forge libraries and Anaconda's main channel. To know if this is the case, we would need to see your list of installed Conda packages in the moose environment.
conda activate moose
conda list
What we are looking for, is that every last package is coming from conda-forge except of course the moose specific packages, which will be coming from https://conda.software.inl.gov/public.
If you see a mix of channels, or blanks. Then that may be the cause. IF that is the case, then:
The fix (according to conda-forge), is to set strict channel priority:
conda config --set channel_priority strict
After which, you should delete the moose the environment, and recreate it.

node.title: When I use polynomial chaos for sensitivity analysis, what happens when the Sobol index is calculated to be all 0?
node.bodyText: Previously, the sobol indicator was null, but later it was adjusted to be all 0. Is there a problem with my input file or is it?

Is this the total Sobol index? One thing I can think about:
Check the coefficients for the polynomial chaos expansion, if they are nonzero and you get a zero sobol index then it is probably right. Even then I'd expect a roundoff value. You can query the coefficients using this object:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/reporters/PolynomialChaosReporter.html
Also, if you ask questions about a wrong input file, past your input file here. Thanks.

node.title: What options do I have for creating a 1-D (line) nodal boundary on a 3D mesh?
node.bodyText:
I am using gmsh. For some reason, MOOSE does not recognize the "physical groups" created if they are 1-D (saying the sidesets do not exist). I tried using ExtraNodesetGenerator and manually listing a few points that should occur on the line, e.g
  [applied_force_disp]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
	input = beam_mesh
	coord = '0 0 200; 0 12.5 200; 0 25 200; 0 -12.5 200; 0 -25 200'
	new_boundary = top-line
  []  

but apparently MOOSE needs those exact points to exist in the mesh. What other options do I have for creating a 1-D boundary to apply a line load (as a displacement, i.e Dirichlet BC)?

Hello
So it s a line load in a 3D mesh?
Can you use a nodeset instead of a sideset?
If the mesh is 3D you wont be able to make a sideset from points
Guillaume

Yes, it's a line load in a 3D mesh. So in gmsh I created a bunch of nodes, selected them, and named them as a physical group. By my understanding this should be a nodeset.
When I export the mesh as an msh file, moose does not even recognize the groups at all.
When I export it as an inp (abaqus) file, i get the error "expected boundary of dimension 2, got 1"
How else can I define these nodes?

looking at the reader, 1D sidesets would be read as nodesets
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/gmsh__io_8C_source.html
in the test example in test/tests/meshgenerators/gmsh_bcs it looks like we can read nodesets from GMSH files

I'm not sure what the issue could be then- I tried creating both point and line groups and neither worked. Could you take a look and try to run it?
https://github.com/richmondodufisan/purple/tree/main/Gradient_Enhanced_Damage
this is more of a gmsh question. @grmnptr do you remember who else is comfortable with gmsh?

node.title: Number of external phase field routine calls during material calculations in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Development Team,
I am in the process of creating an application within the MOOSE framework that integrates an external phase-field program (not an MOOSE phase-field module) with thermal and mechanical solvers for a coupled simulation. The app is designed to solve for the temperature distribution using a heat conduction module and for the strain using a mechanics module. The computed strain and temperature at each node are then input into the phase-field program, which calculates node-specific material properties—namely, thermal conductivity for the thermal solver and elastic modulus for the mechanical solver. Given that a separate phase-field calculation is required for each node, the process is quite time-intensive.
My inquiry pertains to the computational workflow within MOOSE: Will my external phase-field program be called repeatedly to compute material properties at each node within a single time step? Understanding the frequency of these calls is crucial for performance considerations, especially due to the computationally demanding nature of the phase-field calculations.

node.title: Applying Body force in peridynamics module
node.bodyText:
Sir, I am following this book 'Peridynamic Theory and Its Applications' which suggest that the tractions are applied in terms of body force. I wanted to apply traction boundary condition on 1D bar. For that I created a bar of 10mm length. I also created a fictitious boundary layer on left end of the bar which is fixed. At the right edge, I created a separate block to apply the body force equivalent to traction boundary.  I am using BPD with horizon number =1.  Distance between two material point is 1mm.  The resulting displacment is varying linearly as expected but it is not matching with the analytical solution. Also, if I increase the mesh, then displacement value at the end is changing in the order of around 10.
Is there a way to use Body Force kernel properly for peridynamics module? I am attaching my code along with this.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

L=10
H=1
W=1
Hor_num=1
Hn=1
dimension=3
xn=10
yn=1
zn=1
force_dV=100e4

delx=${fparse L/xn}
dely=${fparse H/yn}
delz=${fparse W/zn}
#dV=${fparse delx*dely*delz}
#force_dV= ${fparse force}
M_L_min=${fparse delx/2}
M_L_max=${fparse L-delx/2}
M_H_min=${fparse -dely/2}
M_H_max=${fparse H+dely/2}
M_W_min=${fparse -delz/2}
M_W_max=${fparse W+delz/2}
M_nx=${fparse xn-1}
fb_nx=${fparse Hn}
M_ny=${fparse yn+1}
M_nz=${fparse zn+1}



L_L_min=${fparse M_L_min-Hn*delx}
R_L_max=${fparse M_L_max+delx}

[Mesh]
  type = PeridynamicsMesh
  horizon_number = ${Hor_num}
  [Left_b]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${L_L_min}
    xmax = ${M_L_min}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = ${fb_nx}
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Left_b
	boundary_id_offset = 10
  []
  [Left_b_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Left_b
    subdomain_id = 1
  []
  
  [Mainsec]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${M_L_min}
    xmax = ${M_L_max}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = ${M_nx}
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Mainsec
    boundary_id_offset = 20
  []
  [Mainsec_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Mainsec
    subdomain_id = 2
  []
  [Right_b]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = ${dimension}
    xmin = ${M_L_max}
    xmax = ${R_L_max}
    ymin = ${M_H_min}
    ymax = ${M_H_max}
	zmin = ${M_W_min}
    zmax = ${M_W_max}
    nx = 1
    ny = ${M_ny}
	nz = ${M_nz}
	elem_type=HEX8
    boundary_name_prefix = Right_b
	boundary_id_offset = 30
  []
  [Right_b_id]
    type = SubdomainIDGenerator
    input = Right_b
    subdomain_id = 3
  []
  [combined]
    type = MeshCollectionGenerator
    inputs = 'Left_b_id Mainsec_id Right_b_id'
  []
  construct_side_list_from_node_list=true
  [./gpd]
    type = MeshGeneratorPD
    input = combined
    retain_fe_mesh = false
	blocks_to_pd = '1 2 3'
    merge_pd_blocks = false
    bonding_block_pairs = '1 2; 2 3'
    merge_pd_interfacial_blocks = true
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
  [../]
  [./disp_z]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./node_vol]
  [../]
  [./s11]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./node_area]
    type = NodalVolumePD
    variable = node_vol
  [../]
  [./s11]
    type = NodalRankTwoPD
    variable = s11

	youngs_modulus = 100e9
    poissons_ratio = 0

    rank_two_tensor = stress
	output_type = component
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./left_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 998
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 998
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 998

  [../]
[]



[Kernels]

  [../]
[]


[Modules/Peridynamics/Mechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    formulation = BOND
  [../]
[]

    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 100e9

[]

    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type= NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]
